thread.title: John Besh Accused Of Sexual Harassment And Resigns From His Company
thread.title_full: John Besh Accused Of Sexual Harassment And Resigns From His Company

posts.title: John Besh Accused Of Sexual Harassment And Resigns From His Company
posts.text:
Celebrity Chef Accused Of Sexual Harassment And Resigns From His Company 
Twenty-five women throughout the company have come forward. Most Popular From left: Chef Marcus Samuelsson, Rachael Ray, Chef John Besh, and Chef Aarón Sánchez; Getty Images Oct 24, 2017 NEW ORLEANS (AP) — New Orleans celebrity chef John Besh stepped down from management of the restaurant group that bears his name after a newspaper reported that 25 women who are current or former employees of the business said they were victims of sexual harassment by male co-workers and bosses. New Orleans media outlets said Besh's departure from the business he co-owns was announced to employees Monday. "John has decided to step down from all aspects of operations and to provide his full focus on his family," Shannon White, the woman who is stepping in as CEO, said in an email to staff. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The allegations were published Saturday by NOLA.comThe Times Picayune after an eight-month investigation. Women interviewed said male bosses in the Besh Restaurant Group touched or verbally harassed them and, in a few cases, tried to leverage positions of authority for sex. Besh acknowledged a sexual relationship with an employee, saying in a written statement to NOLA.comThe Times-Picayune that it was consensual, despite the woman's assertions in a complaint to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that she felt pressured. Most Popular The allegations came to light in a time when sexual harassment allegations have been made against other famous men, including Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein, the late Fox News executive Roger Ailes and comedian Bill Cosby. Repercussions from the Besh story were being felt even before the allegations were published. Last month, Alon Shaya, a star chef who rose up through the Besh Group ranks, was dismissed as executive chef at Domenica, Pizza Domenica and his critically acclaimed namesake restaurant, Shaya. Shaya had contacted NOLA.com in August regarding his concerns on how sexual harassment allegations were handled. "I do feel like I was fired for talking ... and for standing up," Shaya said in a follow-up interview Oct. 17. Current and former staff, meanwhile, said in the article and in social media that Shaya did not do enough to stop sexual harassment at the restaurants he ran. On Sunday, Harrah's New Orleans Casino said it was severing ties with Besh and would rename its Besh Steak restaurant in the casino. Nine women interviewed for the NOLA.com story agreed to the use of their names, including Madie Robison. "After being immersed in the culture of the company, I realize my morals and values do not align with the daily practices," Robison wrote in a resignation email, sent to Besh, his business partner Octavio Mantilla and others. In multiple interviews, Robison's complaints included persistent, sexualized comments from peers and supervisors. Robison claimed she also endured the uninvited touching of Mantilla for almost the entirety of her two years at the Besh Group. Mantilla said he doesn't remember touching Robison. "I don't remember touching her at all, not on intention or anything," he said. A Besh Group spokesman said none of the thousands of current or former employees has ever filed an internal complaint alleging sexual harassment in the company's 12 years of existence. Besh and Mantilla said during an Oct. 16 interview that in the past the company had lacked a human resources department to process such claims. The company has one now - its first ever director of human resources took the job Oct. 11, the spokesman told NOLA.com. In his separate, written statement to NOLA.com, Besh said he was working to "rebuild my marriage" and publicly apologized to employees "who found my behavior as unacceptable as I do." "I alone am entirely responsible for my moral failings," he added. "This is not the way the head of a company like ours should have acted, let alone a husband and father." Raymond Landry, an attorney for the restaurant group, gave the news outlet a written statement as well, not mentioning specific allegations, but saying the company is implementing a better procedure for receiving and dealing with complaints. "While we've had a complaint procedure in place that complies with all existing laws, we now recognize that, as a practical matter, we needed to do more than what the law requires and we have revamped our training, education and procedures accordingly," Landry's statement said. thread.title: This Man Went To Extremes To Win At McDonald's Monopoly
thread.title_full: This Man Went To Extremes To Win At McDonald's Monopoly

posts.title: This Man Went To Extremes To Win At McDonald's Monopoly
posts.text:
This Man Went to Extreme Lengths to Win at McDonald's Monopoly 
Impressive? By Madison Flager Oct 25, 2017 McDonald's Monopoly is back in Canada, giving customers a chance to win prizes as elaborate as plane tickets, SUVs, and snowmobiles (Canada, ya know?). There are tons of smaller prizes, like free burgers and gift cards, and McDonald's says there is a 1 in 5 chance of winning every time you play. One Canadian vlogger decided to put those odds to the test by ordering a staggering 100 large fries at once, much to the dismay of every McDonald's employee working that day. He also ordered a large Diet Coke, just for good measure. Since each large fry and medium or large drink comes with two game stamps, that amounted to 202 chances to win. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below YouTube / Furious Pete "Furious Pete" was expecting to win at least 40 prizes, under the assumption that the odds were based on the number of stamps. As shown in the video, it didn't end quite as well as he hoped. After Pete and his wife went through all the monopoly pieces, they discovered they had a grand total of 23 prizes. Most of them were food prizes, meaning they won "a lot of cheeseburgers," as he put it. In the video, Pete says this makes the odds about 1 in 9, which would be correct if each game stamp had a 1 in 5 chance of winning. However, the Official Rules of the game state that the chances of winning are actually based on the number of game pieces (1 piece = 2 stamps). So in that case, McDonald's was pretty accurate in their odds. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below McDonald's Canada After studying the rules a little too intensely, it appears that only the food prize has a 1 in 5 chance of being won, though; as the prize values go up, the odds go down. The chance of winning $10,000 in cash, for example, is 1 in 13 million. In all fairness, if we spent $340.68 on McDonald's, we'd expect to win something a little better than a free sandwich too. Unfortunately, that's not how odds work.

thread.title: Amazon Is No Longer Selling Wine, But Prime Now Users Are Safe
thread.title_full: Amazon Is No Longer Selling Wine, But Prime Now Users Are Safe

posts.author: Madison Flager
posts.title: Amazon Is No Longer Selling Wine, But Prime Now Users Are Safe
posts.text:
Amazon Is No Longer Selling Wine, But Prime Now Users Are Safe 
Always keeping us on our toes, Amazon. Most Popular By Madison Flager Oct 24, 2017 Amazon made our wine-loving hearts sing when it announced expanded alcohol delivery service to 11 new cities across the country earlier this year. That's what made it especially surprising when the company announced it's shuttering its online marketplace, Amazon Wine . Launched at the end of 2012, Amazon Wine was the original way to buy wine on Amazon, before grocery delivery and instant delivery came into play. It's got everything from Martha Stewart's wine line to the trendy wine-in-a-can, as well as mixed packs and cases, sold by wineries and wine brands through Amazon. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below According to The Drinks Business , laws regarding alcohol sales grew complicated once Amazon purchased Whole Foods and acquired brick-and-mortar stores. Despite trying to change regulations, Amazon couldn't keep acting as a middleman between the wineries and customers, for which they received a fee, and stay in accordance with many state laws. So, they decided to close down that part of the site and focus on other ways of selling alcohol. Most Popular RELATED VIDEO: Starting January 1, 2018, sellers won't be able to add more wine products to their account, and users won't be able to browse for wine on the marketplace, TechCrunch reports. Don't freak out yet, though. You can still place orders on Amazon Wine through December 31, and the company is still very much in the wine game by way of Prime Now (hour delivery for the win) and Amazon Fresh (their grocery delivery service), both of which get wine – and beer and liquor, in some places – to you faster than Amazon Wine could. In an email to sellers posted by TechCrunch, Amazon also noted they will continue to offer wine through Whole Foods , so it will be interesting to see if the newly-purchased grocery store gets a more diverse wine inventory in the coming months. Follow Delish on Instagram .

thread.title: People Are Losing It Over This Clear Pumpkin Pie
thread.title_full: People Are Losing It Over This Clear Pumpkin Pie

posts.author: Madison Flager
posts.title: People Are Losing It Over This Clear Pumpkin Pie
posts.text:
People Are Losing It Over This Clear Pumpkin Pie 
Science rocks. By Madison Flager Oct 25, 2017 When it comes to pumpkin , we thought we'd seen it all. Leave it to a restaurant with three Michelin stars to come up with an insane dessert that blows every other pumpkin iteration out of the water. Alinea , named the best restaurant in America three times over, is making waves on social media with its tiny clear pumpkin pie. First posted by Chef de Cuisine Simon Davies on Sept. 24, the diminuitive pumpkin pie makes you feel like you have x-ray vision. You can see the crust and a tiny dollop of whipped cream, but the actual pie slice is completely clear. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below A post shared by Simon Davies (@simon.a.davies) on Sep 24, 2017 at 1:25pm PDT In the photo's comments, Davies says it's made from pumpkin distillate. This is made with a machine called a "rotovap" that creates a clear liquid with the flavor of whatever food you put into it. So while the pie looks like water (or Jell-o), it tastes like pumpkin. Chef and Alinea Owner Grant Achatz posted a picture of several plated mini pies this week, so it looks like the dessert is officially on Alinea's menu. A post shared by Grant Achatz (@grant_achatz) on Oct 21, 2017 at 5:21pm PDT Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Known for its 10- to 22-course dinners and seatings that get booked in minutes, Alinea isn't the kind of place you can just pop in to try the new dish. But, that doesn't mean we won't be stalking Instagram for more sightings of the insane dessert. The response on Twitter and Instagram has been a collective "WOW" followed by, "I need to try that." 10 Foods You Can't Get In The U.S., But Should 
These gems are worth the plane ticket. view gallery 10 Photos 
When it comes to American food, there's no shortage of snacks, drinks, or flavors to choose from. You can walk into a grocery store and choose from 48 different jams, for heaven's sake. And while Amazon has made it easy to get almost anything delivered to your door from anywhere in the world, there are still a few foods that haven't made it to America yet. These are the treats we wish would come to the states, but would 10/10 travel abroad for – they're that good. More Shaq Soda Shaq Soda 
These cream soda tall boys were briefly sold in the U.S. back in 2013, but they didn't last long. For some reason, they are still super popular in Beijing, and have been spotted recently in England and Scotland. Soda Shaq comes in four cream flavors – blueberry, vanilla, strawberry, and orange. They probably contain enough sugar for a lifetime per can, but they're amazingly good. 7-Eleven Kinder Surprise Eggs Kinder Surprise Eggs 
America is getting a version of these next year , which we're thankful for, but they don't come with a surprise toy inside! Apparently it's a ~choking hazard~, which is fair, but we still want the real thing. In other chocolate news, Maltesers are now available in the U.S. (!!!) Getty 1 Of 10 Shaq Soda 
These cream soda tall boys were briefly sold in the U.S. back in 2013, but they didn't last long. For some reason, they are still super popular in Beijing, and have been spotted recently in England and Scotland. Soda Shaq comes in four cream flavors – blueberry, vanilla, strawberry, and orange. They probably contain enough sugar for a lifetime per can, but they're amazingly good. 7-Eleven 2 Of 10 Kinder Surprise Eggs 
America is getting a version of these next year , which we're thankful for, but they don't come with a surprise toy inside! Apparently it's a ~choking hazard~, which is fair, but we still want the real thing. In other chocolate news, Maltesers are now available in the U.S. (!!!) Getty 3 Of 10 Bulmers Irish Cider 
It's not surprising Ireland wins on the cider front, but it is tough you can't find this cider in the states. It's less sweet than an Angry Orchard, and most comparable to a Strongbow. If you're in Ireland or Europe, drink a pint for me. Facebook / Bulmers Irish Cider 4 Of 10 Ketchup Chips 
As two of America's favorite products, the fact that ketchup chips still haven't made it big here is baffling. Pringles has tested the flavor in certain markets, and a Pennsylvania-based company makes them, but they are pretty hard to come by. Head north to Canada though and you'll find them all over. Herr's 5 Of 10 Pan di Stelle 
These Italian cookies are chocolate-hazelnut flavored with little candy stars on top. They're perfect for dunking in tea or milk, and they're annoyingly hard to find here. You can order them on Amazon , but the reviews almost all warn they don't arrive intact. Amazon 6 Of 10 Milka Chocolate 
Despite being manufactured by a U.S. company (Mondelēz International , which used to be Kraft), we're a Hershey's country, not a Milka country. It's pretty heartbreaking, especially considering the bounty of flavors the brand makes. You can find them in rare spots in the US, but mostly in Europe, including Spain, Germany, and France. Getty 7 Of 10 Pocari Sweat 
It looks like an average water bottle (or soda can, depending on what kind you get), but the Japanese drink is actually more like a Gatorade, with electrolytes to keep you from getting dehydrated. Instagram / @geehen 8 Of 10 Bamba 
These peanut-flavored puffs are like the cheese doodles of Israel. Despite the packaging, they're not just for kids, promise. Amazon 9 Of 10 Asahi Pink Beer 
You can find Japan's popular beer in the U.S., but the sakura-season pink cans are only available in Japan. Released in the spring to celebrate cherry blossom season, these pretty cans make drinking beer much more enjoyable. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 10 Of 10 Lemon Soda

thread.title: Foods Only People From The West Coast Can Truly Appreciate - Delish.com

posts.author: Sarah Weinberg
posts.title: Foods Only People From The West Coast Can Truly Appreciate - Delish.com
posts.text: By Sarah Weinberg Oct 26, 2017 West coast natives have a lot to brag about, but little gets us riled up like the local food. Before we continue, try to remove that sprout and avocado stereotype from your brain: The greatest grub here — the kind you crave any time you leave the western seaboard for more than a few weeks — doesn't skew so back-to-the-land. If you don't know what we're talking about, take a second to educate yourself. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below In-N-Out A post shared by Food Porn Daily  (@paulsfoodhaul) on Oct 24, 2017 at 3:57pm PDT Most Popular The rivalry between In-N-Out and Shake Shack will likely never die down, but west coasters can find solace in an Animal-style burger. It's like mom's cooking: You know exactly what the secret ingredient is — Thousand Island dressing, more or less — but your version never turns out half as well. It's-It There's sort of an unspoken war to create the most unexpected ice cream sandwich, so one made with cookies — yes, just cookies — is refreshing. It's-It is the holy grail of frozen treats in California, made with oatmeal cookies, vanilla ice cream, and a thin coat of dark chocolate. Luckily, it's warm enough to eat them year-round. Red Vines A post shared by Todd Hopfner❤️✌️ (@toddhopfner) on Sep 24, 2017 at 2:14am PDT Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The licorice company is headquartered in California, and, as such, has a hold over the entire state and its neighbors. Don't bother trying to sing the praises of its rival strands, Twizzlers. Red Vines taste better, are objectively more popular, and they're even a little bit healthier. California Burritos A post shared by Amanda Blonde Out Of Water (@blondeoutofwater) on Aug 20, 2017 at 10:46am PDT If you balk at the idea of sticking French fries inside a burrito, you're too narrow-minded to live on the west coast. The two-for-one combo alleviates the need to mumble yes when someone asks "Do you want fries with that?", and it's surprisingly delicious. Clam Chowder A post shared by Shannon Pearson (@naturallyshanno) on Aug 14, 2017 at 7:31pm PDT Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The kind of seafood soup you'll find on the west coast is pure, not junked up with tomatoes, as they make it back east. Anyone who's been to Oregon or California knows that's where you'll find chowder mecca. The stuff is served in a bread bowl — do you really need more convincing? Street Tacos A post shared by Jules (@julesfood) on Oct 24, 2017 at 6:52pm PDT Most Popular For starters, they're an insanely cheap meal. If you drop more than a buck and a half per taco, you're at the wrong stand. Plus, California and Arizona are hubs for authentic Mexican food. A taco consumed anywhere else will never stack up. Hot Dog On A Stick A post shared by Jill Penuel (@jillpenuel) on Oct 7, 2017 at 5:27pm PDT Don't try to call this just a corndog. The employees dip hot dogs in batter and fry 'em up on the spot, so it's basically dinner and a show. There are a few locations east of the Mississippi, but this fast food spot is a staple of west coast food courts. Dutch Crunch Bread A post shared by High Functioning Foodie  (@thekaloriekut) on Sep 20, 2017 at 5:08pm PDT San Francisco's famous sourdough is great, but there's something to be said about a food so local, barely anyone outside the region knows of it. That's the case with Dutch Crunch, a bread that's smothered with rice flour and sugar before baking, so its top develops a crunchy, crackled coating. Fans of Togo's (the west coast's answer to Subway) will remember it fondly from the bread line-up. Garlic Fries A post shared by Gujju's Foods (@gujjusfoods) on Aug 29, 2017 at 5:38am PDT If you don't come home from a Giants game with your breath reeking of garlic, you're doing it wrong. The team's home stadium is beloved for its iconic garlic fries concession. They're so good, even McDonald's locations in the region started to make them. Follow Delish on Instagram .

posts.title: This Blogger's Chocolate Chip Cookie Recipe Is Going Viral - Delish.com
posts.text:
This Blogger's Chocolate Chip Cookie Recipe Is Going Viral 
"It's all in the pan-bang." Most Popular By Lauren Miyashiro Oct 27, 2017 It's not every day that a chocolate chip cookie makes national headlines. So when we saw that the The New York Times wrote about one blogger's recipe, we dropped everything to try it — and so did just about everyone else on the planet. Pictures of the abnormally wrinkly, behemoth chocolate chip cookie are everywhere on Instagram. A post shared by @42burners on Nov 10, 2016 at 11:16am PST Advertisement - Continue Reading Below BUY NOW: Nordic Ware Sheet Pan, $13; amazon.com . The woman behind the craze is Sarah Kieffer, author of The Vanilla Bean Baking Book , and the secret to her raved-about cookies has nothing to do with baking time or ingredients."It's all in the pan-bang," she told The Times . Halfway through baking the cookies, when they're slightly puffed in the center, she asks you to drop the pan against the oven rack — not gently, but from about 4 inches up. The point is to have the center of each cookie to fall down. A couple minutes later, once the cookie puffs back up again, you bang it again … and again and again. Rian Handler Most Popular BUY NOW: The Vanilla Bean Baking Book, $19; amazon.com It's not the most calming process, but it can be pretty therapeutic if you're having a long, frustrating week. Others around you, however, might get a bit annoyed. One tester I know commented that her dad "did not appreciate" all the ruckus in the kitchen. But noise complaints aside, the technique really works. It creates tree trunk-esque rings in the cookie like we've never seen before. When we baked a batch (using the same recipe) without banging the pan, the cookies spread a lot more and were significantly crunchier. The banged cookies were far superior in texture. The inside was perfectly chewy, the exterior was slightly crisp and caramelized, and all those sunken rings of cookie were ever so slightly softer. Though pretty dang perfect in taste, this will likely not be our go-to recipe. It takes too much time! First, you need to freeze the dough for 15 minutes before baking. (If you don't, they'll spread like cray.) Then you can only bake one sheet at a time, since the cookies need to bake in the center of the oven. And on the baking sheets, you only get 4 to 6 cookies because they're so enormous. Julia Smith We will, however, save this recipe for a day when we have a lot of pent-up anger and have a few hours to kill (those days exist, right?). Or when we just need a really, really good cookie. RELATED VIDEO: Download the Delish app today. Follow Delish on Instagram .

While you're putting the finishing touches on your costume and preparing to drain your neighbors of as much Halloween candy as possible, fuel up for the night ahead with even more free treats. As if we needed another reason to love this ghoulish holiday, several restaurants are getting into the Halloween spirit, offering up freebies and deals for customers who show up in costume — in some cases you can take advantage even if you're not dressed up, but it's more fun if you do!

thread.title: Weight Watchers is coming out with its own wine
thread.title_full: Weight Watchers is coming out with its own wine

posts.title: Weight Watchers is coming out with its own wine
posts.text: By Julie H. Case Oct 30, 2017 Diet empire Weight Watchers is getting into the wine business — kind of. The company just announced a lower-calorie Sauvignon Blanc, called Cense, which has fewer points per glass than the typical vino. It may seem like a random brand extension, until you see the raw data. Wine is the second most-tracked beverage — coffee being first — according Ryan Nathan, Vice President of Products, Licensing, and Ecommerce at Weight Watchers . So, the company partnered with California producer Truett-Hurst Winery (which makes wines for retailers like Trader Joe's). The goal was to create a wine that clocked in at three points, rather than the typical four, says Nathan. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The trick turned out to be in an algorithm that kept sugar and calories low — so a 5-oz. glass contains just 85 calories, compared to the typical 120 — but it also lowered the alcohol level. Most wines are labeled between 9 and 15 percent, with Sauvignon Blancs coming in around 11-13.5. Cense is 9.6 percent alcohol by volume. Weight Watchers Most Popular Developing a lower-calorie wine while also ensuring the wine tasted good wasn't easy, says Phil Hurst, Co-Founder and President and CEO of Truett-Hurst Winery. The company initially imagined that if they started with a big, round red — like a Zinfandel or Syrah from California's Dry Creek — and reduced the alcohol, they'd still have a wine that was incredibly robust. They were wrong. In fact, it took the company two years to land on its ideal formula. Winemaker Ross Reedy posited that choosing a naturally aromatic wine that was crisp, high in acidity, zesty in flavor, and didn't need oak treatment — and then reducing the alcohol — would do the trick. So, they turned to Sauvignon Blanc. Grapes for Cense are sourced from a vineyard in Marlborough and made into wine there, then the wine is shipped to the U.S., where the alcohol is reduced and the wine is bottled. Sometimes when you put a lower alcohol wine in a lineup it can seem thin or wimpy in comparison to its higher alcohol brethren. Not so with the Cense. After sampling a bottle, we were surprised to find how much it tasted like a classic Sauvignon Blanc. The nose is heavy on the grapefruit — mostly ruby red grapefruit — plus a good bit of Meyer lemon, followed by a hint of candied pineapple. Those aromas carry through to the flavor, which is citrusy with a touch of green jalapeno-like notes. The Cense has screaming acidity, although not mouth-puckeringly so. As of today, you can buy a bottle at Censewines.com starting at $15, and at Kroger stores where it retails for $13.99. The two companies expect to launch a rosé in the near future. Follow Delish on Instagram .

posts.text: Nov 1, 2017 GET THE RECIPE HERE . Happy November 1st, folks! I know, I know. It's super crazy and hard to believe that we're just a few short weeks away from Thanksgiving. Very soon you will be preparing a huge turkey feast for too many people, or you will be expected to bring an awesome, thoughtful dish to a friend's house. So, START PLANNING PEOPLE! Alexa Payesko Advertisement - Continue Reading Below BUY NOW: Nordic Ware Sheet Pan, $13; amazon.com . First up is appetizers, arguably the most crowd-pleasing category because the foods are usually fun. (Because cheese.) There are a ton of recipes to choose from, but this year, only one matters. Bloomin'. Brie. Bread. In the world of cheese, brie is definitely the safe choice. (It's just so freakin' creamy!) And everyone loves it baked — whether it's wrapped in puff pastry or slathered with fruit preserves. What most people are neglecting to do, however, is baking a whole wheel inside of a bread bowl. A bloomin' bread bowl. It's kinda like pull-apart bread, where each chunk you tear off is super garlicky and perfectly toasty. But in the middle is just a pool of glorious molten cheese. Alexa Payesko Most Popular To "bloom" the bread, all you need to do is slice off the top of a large boule then dig out a well. (Save those scooped out bread pieces for dunking later.) Carefully, cut down around the edges of the bread to create the slices that people will tear after baking, then load it up with cheese and bake it 'til you make it. No joke, this might outshine the big bird this year. And the mashed potatoes. And the stuffing and the pie ... RELATED VIDEO:

posts.title: The Worst Thing About Papa John's Pizza Isn't That It Tastes Bad
posts.text:
Papa John's Says Their Sales Are Down Because Of The NFL Protests 
"This is an example of poor leadership." Getty By Megan Friedman Nov 1, 2017 Papa John's pizza sales are currently in a slump, and the company is pointing fingers at an unlikely source: football. Bloomberg reports that Papa John's says the NFL's latest controversies are to blame for lower pizza sales. That's because some people are boycotting watching games while players kneel during the National Anthem, so that means fewer people see Papa John's ads and decide to order pizza. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below "The NFL has hurt us by not resolving the current debacle to the players' and [team] owners' satisfaction," Papa John's founder and CEO John Schnatter reportedly said on a conference call. "NFL leadership has hurt Papa John's shareholders." The company frequently runs commercials during games, and said they were going to start moving some of their ad dollars away from the NFL. "This should have been nipped in the bud a year and a half ago," Schnatter added. "Like many sponsors, we are in contact with the NFL and once the issue is resolved between the players and the owners, we are optimistic that the NFL's best years are ahead. But good or bad, leadership starts at the top, and this is an example of poor leadership." Most Popular To be fair, chain founder John Schnatter is an outspoken Republican and Trump supporter , so he may be making a political statement by blaming NFL protesters for the sales slump. But his claim may not be entirely unfounded. A Bloomberg analyst said if fewer Americans are watching football, fewer people are ordering their usual pepperoni pizzas to sit and watch the game. Papa John's has a sponsorship deal with the NFL, and didn't have an issue with sales when ratings fell in 2016. The NFL did not respond to the Washington Post 's request for comment. Follow Delish on Instagram .

posts.text:
Sam's Club Is Selling A Massive, 44-Ounce Cinnamon Roll 
There's no such thing as too much dough. Sam's Club By Madison Flager Nov 1, 2017 If you're in need of a holiday breakfast that will feed the whole family – and neighborhood, for that matter – Sam's Club has you covered. The big-box store is known for its oversize products, like last month's 72-ounce pumpkin cheesecake , and its newest ready-to-eat item definitely lives up to the reputation. Weighing in at a crazy 44 ounces, the supersize cinnamon roll is what sugary dreams are made of. For comparison, one of those Big Texas cinnamon rolls you'd find in a vending machine or gas station clocks in at a mere four ounces, and an entire tube of Cinnabon cinnamon rolls is 13 ounces. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Sam's Club According to Sam's Club representatives, this massive version of a classic cinnamon roll has layers of sweet cinnamon and white icing dripping over the top. You'll need a membership to pick one up (or a friend who's willing to hook it up), but in typical Sam's Club fashion, it's a steal. The rolls sell for $4.98 each, and are available now through December 31. RELATED VIDEO:
